testimony: Mr Strydom, are you ready to proceed?
Yes Chairperson.  The next applicant we are calling is Mqambeleni Buthelezi.  He is number 1 on the list.
Mr Buthelezi, what language are you going to speak?
You may be seated.  Yes Mr Strydom?
Mr Buthelezi, you have signed a Form 1, a document that I am going to show you now.  This is on page 46 of the bundle.  Do you identify your signature on page 47?
There is also an annexure to that document, on page 48 and 49.  Has this document been explained to you yet again and do you accept the contents thereof?
Certain particulars were required and you answered them.  Do you stand by the answers given on page 53, 54, 55, 56, 57 and 58 of the index of the bundle?
Yes, if those are the answers that I know.
You also made an affidavit which is contained on page 59 and 60.  Do you confirm your signature on page 60?

Whilst we are with the affidavit, I am going to read certain portions and then you can confirm that evidence.
	You moved into the hostel during the course of 1992, is that correct?
I went to the hostel in 1990.
The reference to 1992, is in fact wrong, it should read 1990 is that what you are saying?
Previously you were staying at the Sebokeng hostel, is that right?
Why did you leave the Sebokeng hostel?
I left the hostel because of the violence that had erupted between the IFP and the ANC, so that I was forced to leave the hostel.
Are you a member of the Inkatha Freedom Party?
When did you become a member of that party?

In your statement on page 60, you make the allegation that IFP members were killed, assaulted, burnt, intimidated in the township, including Boipatong.
	Do you know who these people were that attacked and assaulted and burnt and intimidated IFP members?
It was the ANC responsible for this.  It was the ANC.
Mr Buthelezi, would you please speak up so that people at the back of the hall could hear what you are saying?
You further make the allegation that the situation got to a stage that there was a political war going on between the hostel and the ANC sympathisers in the townships.  Why do you say so?
Would you say that your own life was in danger during that period?
Yes, my life was in danger because I was under very serious threat because of the manner in which the ANC was doing things.
Could you move freely in Boipatong and other towns in the Vaal Triangle?
No, I was not able to.  From 1990 when the violence erupted, I think it was on the 22nd of July, I started experiencing this problem that I could not move about freely.
Of which year?  Which year do you refer to with reference to the 22nd of July, of which year?
You make the allegation that the residents of Boipatong, marched to kwaMadala hostel at a certain stage.  When was that?
Would you please repeat the question?

In your statement you say that the residents of Boipatong at a certain stage marched to kwaMadala hostel, they couldn't get into the hostel, they wanted to kill us because we are IFP supporters.
	Can you just place some date on that happening?
Yes, this march was organised by the ANC, but they did not gain entry into the hostel.  We were there as residents of the hostel, and they did not manage to gain entry.
Was that before the attack on Boipatong?
Yes, that is exactly how it happened.  Often times the ANC had a programme that was meant for the elimination of IFP members.
You further make the allegation that your family members were killed in Boipatong.  Can you give more particulars?
Yes.  What I am saying is that I have family members who were killed at Boipatong, but at least I know that there were IFP members who were killed at Boipatong.
That reference there to family, is that direct family or also IFP supporters that you refer to?
Where did you come from originally, before you came to the Vaal Triangle?
I am from the Umsinga area in kwaZulu Natal.
In the hostel, you were an office bearer, in fact you were the leader of the Youth Brigade, is that right?
Who were the other people on your committee?
The structure consisted of eight members, I was the Chairman.  The vice-Chairperson was Victor Mthembu.  There was a Secretary too.
Yes, I do remember his name.  The Assistant-Secretary was Matabela.
Yes, but can we just get back to the Secretary, maybe I missed the name.  Can you give the name of the Secretary, the name that you remember?
Zwi.  I knew him as Zwi.
Yes, and the other people on this committee, who were they?
The Assistant-Secretary was Matabela.  Our Publicity Officer was Dingane.

Mr Buthelezi, please raise your voice so that the people at the back can hear what you are saying.
	You are addressing everyone in this hall.
I will try to do so.
You also mentioned a person by the name of Dingane.
He was the Publicity Officer.  He was Dinane Nqumalo.
Do you remember any other names?
Can you please provide them to the Committee?
You have given six committee members, do you remember the names of the other two?
The Treasurer was Bazuka Mthimkhulu.  His assistant was Themba Mabote.
What were the functions of the Youth Committee in the hostel?
The functions of the Committee, it was to inform the hostel residents of the guidelines and policy objectives of the IFP.
Other functions included addressing meetings on what needs to be done, and what should be the proper conduct when attending rallies.  Those were the functions of that committee.
Who were responsible to organise rallies?

Various rallies were organised at leadership level in Johannesburg, they would inform us if there was a rally.
	As members and supporters of the organisation, we would have to attend.
But in the hostel, if there is now a call for a rally from Johannesburg, who would organise the rally in the hostel to get the people together?
We as a committee, in conjunction with the senior committee, would organise that the rally is attended.
Talking about rallies, is there an annual rally held at Ulundi in kwaZulu Natal?

As far as I know, there is usually an annual conference and then an annual congress.
	There is a national conference in July.
Does that take place every year?
Yes, every year in July, there is a conference.
After the Boipatong attack, that is now the July after the 17th of June 1992, did you attend such a rally in kwaZulu-Natal at Ulundi?
Unfortunately at that time, I was in prison, so I was not able to attend.  I was in prison from the 30th of June until December of that year.

To turn to the attack itself, it is common cause that the attack took place on the 17th of June 1992.
	When did you for the first time, become aware that there was going to be such an attack?

This was a matter that we had discussed before, because of the fact that the ANC had been attacking us.  We discussed that we should launch a revenge attack because of what the ANC was doing to our members.
I want to enquire about approximate date when you became aware that such a possibility existed that there would be an attack.

Although I cannot recall the specific meeting at which this matter was discussed, because the minute book may have been confiscated by the police, but there was a meeting where we discussed this matter.
	It could have been two weeks or even a week before the actual attack took place.
During that meeting, was it already decided exactly when the attack would be launched?
It was not decided.  I am sure there was a reason why this could not be done.
At this meeting prior to the attack, were you in favour of the attack?

I was in favour of the attack, because of the situation, the difficulties that we were experiencing.  Even though this was against IFP policy, the attacks that we were experiencing, were really difficult on us.
Who would have been responsible to make the final decision about the attack?
It was Mr Mkhize, the Induna, who was responsible at the hostel.
When did you establish that the attack was going to take place on the 17th of June, when did you get the date of the attack?

As I have already mentioned, the date had not been decided upon before.  I heard the alarm going off on the day of the 17th.  That was when we took the decision that we were going to go out and launch the attack.
In your statement you say that you did not go with the other people to attack Boipatong, is that correct?
Did you stay behind at the hostel?
In the light of the fact that you were in favour of the attack, why did you not join the other attackers that went to Boipatong?
On that day, I was not feeling well.  I was developing a cold.  Therefore my state of health was not perfect, that was the reason why I could not join the other people when they went out to attack.
Do you have the decease called asthma?
Will the question please be repeated?
I want to enquire about his health, about a decease called asthma, if he has got that decease?
No, it is just a chest problem, not asthma.
If you were not feeling ill on that particular day of the attack, would you have joined the attack?
On that night when the alarm was sounded, did you go to the stadium, or did you stay in your room?
I did not go, I remained in my room.  I was even afraid of going outside, to avoid being exposed to the temperature outside.
When the people returned from Boipatong, did you see them?
Unfortunately I had fallen asleep, but I did hear Mr Khanyile coming in, because we share the same room.
When did you establish some further detail about the attack?

I only heard the following morning information to the effect that the attack had been launched, but I must indicate that I only managed to gather more information from the news bulletins because I did not have time to discuss with those who had launched the attack.  I went to town to buy some few things and I came back.
After the attack, did Mr Themba Khoza come to the hostel?
As far as I know, I saw him on a Friday and he was in the company of police.  The white men was - there was a white man who was in charge of the police.  They all came together.
Did you at any stage hear Mr Khoza saying that loot that came from, and other property that came from Boipatong, should be burnt?
Do you know Mr Vanana Zulu?
Do you know if he was in the hostel on the 17th of June 1992?
No, he was not at the hostel on that day.  He had gone home to Natal.  I think the attack was launched two or so days, after he had left.
Mr Victor Mthembu, you already testified was your vice-Chairman on your committee.  He testified here that he saw you in Boipatong, what do you say about that?  That is on the night of the attack?
He was making a mistake, he assumed that because I was one of the leaders, I must have been present.  That is a mistake.
Were you aware of any hitsquads that were operating from the kwaMadala hostel under the leadership of Victor Keswa?
I have no information about the hitsquads, I know nothing about that.
Do you know that a certain amount of people, or what do you say about the allegation that a certain amount of people came from Umsinga just prior to the attack, to assist in the attack on Boipatong?

There were no men, there was no contingent from Umsinga.  There was no such a group of people.  I spent a lot of time here, working in the Vaal.  There was a lot of violence going on.
	The one group of people from Umsinga, are the ones who came to Johannesburg with us, to work.
Were there people from Umsinga who were resident at the hostel, apart from you?
Yes, there were, but there were not more than 10.
Keswa, where did he come from?  Is that the same person as Keswa?
You say he came from where?
As far as I know, he is from Zone 7.
Do you know where his original home was?
I do not know where he originates from, but I know him from the location, the township.
Did he associate himself with the people who came from Umsinga?
Whilst we are referring to Victor Keswa, according to your knowledge, was he in the hostel on the 17th of June 1992?
As far as I know, Mr Keswa was in prison.  He had been arrested a few days before.
The name Rubin, which would be a reference to Tebogo Rubin Magubane, was he from Umsinga?
According to my knowledge, he is from Johannesburg, either from Tshiawelo or Masilela, but he is not from kwaZulu-Natal.
And Lucky Stikenawu, was he from Umsinga?
He is from Johannesburg, not kwaZulu Natal.
Do you know a person by the name of Themba Kubeka?  Was he from Umsinga?
No.  The Themba Kubeka I know, also comes from Johannesburg.  His home was at Small Farms.
Sipho Thomas Lukhozi, is he a person from Umsinga?
With reference to Sipho, I also know him to be from Johannesburg.
The other applicants, Sipho Buthelezi, will still testify.  Do you know if he is from Umsinga?
I know that he was born and bred here in Johannesburg, from Zone 12.
And Jack Mbele, or Dondo, he has already testified.  Is he from Umsinga?
I know him to be from Sharpville, not Umsinga.
Do you know a person by the name of Andries Matanzima Nosenga?
No, I do not know him.  I have never seen him before.
Do you know if he was part of the attack on Boipatong, as far as your knowledge goes?

I first heard of his name, while I was in prison.  I heard that he had come to the hostel on ANC instruction.
	I do not have full details of what happened there, because I was already incarcerated, in prison, by then, but I do not know that person.  As a youth leader, if he had been in the hostel whilst I was there, I would know him because every youth person, any person who was at that level, was brought to me and I would have records of such a person, so I would know him if he was at the hostel at the time.
According to your records, was Mr Nosenga at the hostel on the 17th of June 1992?  Can I add something, your records and your recollection?
No, I do not have any records.
You were convicted in the criminal court, is that correct?
And the Court found that you were in Boipatong on the night of the attack, was that a correct finding?
The Court insisted that I had been present in the attack, although I tried to explain that I did not take part because of ill health.  That is why I was convicted.

I've got no further questions.  Sorry, I in fact have got, I forgot about something, sorry.
	Do you or did you know a person by the name of Nomvula?
Yes, I did know that person, although I was not close to her.
And did you hear what happened to her?
I heard that she was burnt.
Was that before the attack on Boipatong?
Mr David Mbele, did you know him?
I heard about him.  I did not know the people of Tserela very well.
And Mr Khumalo?  Sorry, can I just ask you, you said you heard something about Mr Mbele, what did you hear about him?
I heard that he had been killed.
I knew Mr Khumalo and I also heard that he had been burnt and killed.
Did you know a Mr Elias Sebiya who was staying in Boipatong and his address was 2202 Sihiso Street?

I knew of a certain Sebiya, whose car had been burnt down and he was assaulted and he had to be hospitalised.
	I am not sure whether you are referring to the very same one that I do know.

Thank you, I've got no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR STRYDOM
Mr Buthelezi, did Themba Khoza come to the hostel often to address meetings, or was it only on special occasions?
As far as I know, he did not frequent the hostel, unless there was something that he had to inform us about, that is on political matters.
After the attack, was he at the hostel only once during that week, or twice?  Will you know that?
After the attack, did he come to the hostel during that week, once or twice?

According to my knowledge, he came twice.  He came on a Friday and he also returned midweek when the police had cordoned off the hostel.
	We requested him to come and negotiate with the police that we should be able to go out and buy ourselves food and necessary things that we needed at the hostel.
Were you aware that there was a decision that all the loot from Boipatong had to be burnt?
As I mentioned before, that I went to town early the following morning.  I did not get to hear of that information.
Was he a member of the Youth Brigade?
Do you know whether he went out into the townships to shoot people?

I do not have any information to that effect.  What I can explain is that there were no set times regarding the movements of the people in or out of the hostel, people were free to move as they pleased.
The day to day business of the Youth League, was it run by all eight members of the Youth League leadership or was there a smaller committee, who did the everyday work of the Youth Brigade?
If for instance, we were to have a meeting, we would meet as a committee to formulate an agenda.
Did the police, before the attack on Boipatong, did any police come and talk to the residents of kwaMadala?  Was there a meeting addressed by the police at kwaMadala before this attack?
The police usually came to search the hostel.  They never came to address us on any matter.
Did you know Mr Peens from the police, Pedro Peens?
I do not know that person.  I would not even be able to identify him.
Did Themba Khoza ever address a meeting where white policemen also addressed the meeting, before the attack?

I have no further questions, thank you.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS PRETORIUS

As it pleases you Mr Chairman.  Mr Buthelezi, you testified that you heard an alarm on the 17th of June and I gather the reason for the alarm was for the people to gather at the stadium.  Can you say what time you heard this more or less?
I think it was around eight o'clock in the evening.
You say that Mr Khanyile came into the room. Was this before or after the attack?
When the alarm rang, he went out for a very long time.  Although I could not have looked at my watch, but he was gone for quite a long time.
When Mr Khanyile was in the room, can you estimate what time this was more or less?
Unfortunately I did not look at the watch, because I was not well.

I don't have any further questions, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR DA SILVA
Do you have records of all the members of the Youth Brigade?
At the time I did have a list of everyone.  Unfortunately when the police were investigating this matter, they confiscated all those records, and they were never returned to me.
Could you say that you knew every single member of the Youth Brigade?
Yes, I did know them, but there were many members and I was not with them all the time, but there are some that I do remember.
How many members would you say that there approximately were at the time of the attack?

Unfortunately I cannot give a figure, because there were many.
	The book of records would be the one to actually give an exact number.
Could you say though that every IFP member or Youth Brigade member, was carrying a card?  Did he have to carry a certain card to be a member?
A Youth Brigade member had to have a card, so that we would also be certain that he indeed was a member.
Are you certain that you do not know of a person known as Matanzima, maybe not Nosenga, but the name Matanzima, does that not ring a bell somewhere?
I do not know that name.  I heard of that Matanzima when I was in prison, in the Pretoria prison.
If Matanzima would give evidence that he was carrying a card, that he was a card carrying member, would you accept that he was a member of the IFP at the time?
Before my arrest, I would dispute that he was a card carrying member, because I have never met him, I do not know him.
But you just said that you didn't know everybody because there were too many people to know?  No comment?

As I have already explained, that I do not know that name.  I just heard of him later.
	He would have to show or give evidence of when and how he joined the organisation.  Secondly I am not the person who was responsible for signing up new members.  That was the Secretary's job.
	My job was to see to it that every member carried their card.
How could you dispute whether he was a member or not, wouldn't the Secretary be able to confirm that?
What I dispute is that I have never seen nor heard of the name Matanzima before my arrest.
Do you know of any ANC members who would join the IFP at the hostel, and then how would you treat such members if they joined?

If a person wanted to join the IFP, we would question his background, and he would have to explain where he comes from.
	We would accept new members because we were on a recruiting drive.

According to Matanzima in his statement, he tells, he says that when he left and joined the hostel, you were at first suspicious  but then after a while, your suspicions were allayed and you accepted him in the Brigade.
When Nosenga says you, is he referring specifically to this witness or to the hostel residents in general?
Mr Chairperson, I would expect that he was referring to the committee, either the committee or the Youth Brigade itself, who would accept him as a member.
What are your instructions in that regard?

I have no instructions except that he says that he was accepted after some time of suspicion.
	We will get further evidence from him in this regard, anyway.
What is your answer Mr Buthelezi?
Will you please repeat the question?
Are you aware of any ANC members that joined the IFP, and how would they be treated once they joined?

I thought the question that you have just asked is the question, what you were putting to him is that Nosenga says in his statement that when he came to the hostel, they were first suspicious.  Isn't that the question that you wanted to put?
That is the question, I apologise Mr Chairman.

Yes.  That is the question that you should put to him.  I put it to you that Matanzima at first, when he joined, you were suspicious or the party was suspicious of him, according to him, and after a while, the suspicions were allayed, and he was accepted as a full fledged member of the IFP party.
As I have already mentioned it before, I do not know him.  Maybe he joined the organisation after my arrest.
You mentioned that your life was in danger.  How was your life directly in danger at the time prior to the attack on Boipatong?

My life was in danger in relation to the ANC's attack on Inkatha members.  I always had to be on the lookout for the ANC, be it at the taxi's or anywhere.
	Even though I was not written Inkatha all over my face, but they could have easily recognised me.  My life was in danger for a very long time, from 1990 right up to the time when the violence subsided.
However, you were not afraid to go to the shops the day after the attack on Boipatong?
I was afraid, but I was then forced by circumstances.  I had to go out and buy food.  I had to accompany people who were on their way to work, so as to get out of the hostel and buy food.
You mentioned that there was an ANC programme to eliminate IFP members.  What was such a programme, how were you aware of such a programme?

As I am explaining that this was the programme of the ANC wherein the IFP was attacked all over the place.
	It was their campaign to burn and kill members of the IFP.  That is why I am saying so.
Where did the Youth Brigade get its money from?  You mentioned a Treasurer, where would they collect monies from?

Here I am referring to the structures of the IFP when I am talking about the Treasurer.  For example we would raise money by way of contributions from the members within and these monies would then be used accordingly.
What is your standard of education?
Unfortunately I have never been to a classroom situation.
You mentioned that the meeting that you attended prior to the attack, all right, at this meeting, was the attack discussed in detail?
In your opinion would you say that the attack itself, was just a random attack or was it well planned?
The attack happened randomly on that day.  People were driven by anger and they therefore had to do exactly that, attack.  But nobody had planned beforehand what was going to happen on that day.

I put it to you that Matanzima Nosenga is going to give evidence that in fact this attack was planned, that he was part of the planning, he was part of the crowd when it was planned for, and that every detail was discussed?

He can come forward with that information, but as far as I know, I did indicate that I have never seen him.  I don't know him.
	If he has that information, he should come forward and divulge that, the implication of the police, the killing of the people at Tserela, etc.  I think if that is the case, he must have been captured in a photo shot by the police, if he was present.
Were you aware of the IFP leadership's unwillingness or not being in favour of this attack?

The leadership or the entire leadership of the IFP, have or the IFP as a whole, have a constitution which is opposed to the attack of people, but we as residents of kwaMadala hostel had been angered by the killing of so many of our members by the ANC here in the Vaal and we therefore decided as residents that these people from Tserela should be attacked.
	Anything can go ahead and happen, that is how it happened.

But my question was, were you aware that they were reluctant to proceed, they wanted to speak first to see if they could not communicate and discuss with the leaders of the Boipatong location before any attack took place?
Yes, I know that the leadership of the IFP were opposed following the constitution of the organisation.

You say you only learnt of the attack, the day after the attack?  When the dwellers or the hostel residents came back, weren't they shouting, changing, singing, victorious, happy with what they had just done?  Didn't you hear any noise, weren't you awaken by any sounds?
No, there wasn't any such noise.
Did the dwellers just come home and go back to sleep like nothing happened?

I think so because I also heard my roommate or I only saw my roommate the following day, I didn't see him come in at night.
	I did not hear any noise at all.
Did anybody notice your absence from the attack and were you ever asked why you did not participate in the attack?
No, I was not questioned at all.  No one questioned me about that.
Did Khanyile, your roommate not ask you where were you in the attack?
He was the one who knew that I was not well, seeing that he was my roommate.
So he knew that you did not participate in the attack?

And Matanzima Nosenga is going to give evidence that in fact a meeting took place about two weeks before the attack, at which meeting members of the police, one Mr Peens and members, IFP leaders, all gave speeches.  Can you confirm this?
I know not of such a meeting.

Nosenga is going to give evidence that at this meeting Themba Khoza and Mr Peens chaired the meeting, speeches were given by Matwana Zulu, one Darkie, Katheni and Dani.  Does such a meeting ring a bell, do any of these people ring a bell to you?

Ma'am, shouldn't you break the question so that he can respond properly?  The first portion of the question relates to the fact that these individuals you have described, gave speeches and they chaired the meeting.
I shall do that Mr Chairman.
Yes, so that he can respond properly.

Are you aware of a meeting, or Mr Nosenga is going to give evidence that  a meeting took place that was chaired by both Mr Peens, which is a member of the Murder and Robbery Squad and Themba Khoza.  Are you aware of such a meeting?
Did Themba Khoza chair any meeting two weeks prior to the attack?
He did not chair any meeting.
Did he give a speech at any hearing or rally about two weeks prior to the attack?
At any what?   At any hearing or rally?
As far as I know, I saw him delivering a speech for the last time at a rally at Jabulani.  That was the last time.
You mentioned that a rally did take place about two weeks before the attack.  Could you say who gave speeches at this rally or who spoke?
He talked of a meeting, didn't he?
I did.  I apologise I am using the word meeting, but I mean rally, hearing, a rally.
I mean the applicant, did the applicant not talk of a meeting which was approximately two weeks prior to the attack?
Is that what you are referring to as a rally?
I am, I am sorry, yes I am Mr Chairman.  I am referring to the meeting.  Are you aware of any other persons who gave a speech at the meeting two weeks prior to the attack?
The meeting that we had as far as I know, was a meeting that was not attended by people from outside.  I did not see them.
My question to you was, do you remember anybody who spoke at that meeting, besides Mr Khoza?
He never said that Mr Khoza spoke at that meeting, he in fact said the last time he heard him speaking was at the rally at Jabulani.
Excuse me Ma'am.  Please be very careful what you put to the witness, please try and put to the witness what he has said.
Can you tell us who spoke at this meeting that was private?
Mr Buthelezi, you spoke about a meeting that was held approximately two weeks prior to the attack, do you recall that?
What you are being asked is, can you tell us who spoke at that meeting?  Do you understand the question?
Is that what you want to ask?
Thembinkosi Khumalo,  Chairperson of Inkatha, followed by Induna Mkhize.  Those are the people who delivered speeches and we also had Matwana  Zulu and local residents of the hostel itself.

Mr Nosenga is going to give evidence to the effect that he was at this meeting, and that at this meeting, he had heard Themba Khoza speak and Themba Khoza saying that a certain insect should be killed, referring to the Boipatong residents, due to a certain Inkatha member having been killed in a location.  What is your comment to that?
That is an error.  I did not come across any such speech.

Mr Nosenga is also going to give evidence that Themba Khoza said at the meeting to kill the dogs, again referring to the Boipatong residents, because they were not human beings, and he said that the Indunas agreed with the statements of Themba Khoza?
I did indicate that I know nothing about this, and resultantly I cannot give you an answer thereto.  I don't know anything about this.

I put it to you that Mr Nosenga is also going to give evidence to the effect that Mr Peens, or Sergeant Peens from the Police Force, spoke in Afrikaans, he also spoke at the meeting, and that it was translated.

Again, I maintain that there is nothing that I can say about Nosenga.  I did not come across such kind of a speech.  I am here before this Commission to divulge the truth because I am not in court now.  I am here before the Commission and therefore I have to tell everything I know.
	I would have said the same about the Nosenga issue if I knew it.  It is very difficult for me to start telling a lie now here.
Mr Nosenga is going to give evidence and has made a statement to the effect that Mr Peens agreed with Themba Khoza and also said that he would supply caspirs near the location.
I would stick to the same response, I know nothing about that.  Maybe he was communicating with Khoza, but really I have not heard of anything like that.

Let me then just put it to you, what he will say is that Sergeant Peens and Dani also said that they would supply Rooikop with weapons and they would give them to Themba Khoza who would bring them to the hostel.

That is an error.  We did not have a problem with reference to weapons, because Qunchu was the one who was supplying us with firearms.
	I don't know how this Peens story comes in here.
Are you aware of a meeting that took place on about the 14th of June 1992?
I do not remember, I don't know.

I have already said that I do not remember any meeting held on that day.
